title: Palantir Technologies
content:

'''Palantir Technologies''' is a [[Public company|public]] American company that specializes in [[big data]] [[analytics]]. Headquartered in [[Denver, Colorado]], it was founded by [[Peter Thiel]],<ref>{{Cite news|last=Steinberger|first=Michael|date=2020-10-21|title=Does Palantir See Too Much?|language=en-US|work=The New York Times Magazine |url=https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/10/21/magazine/palantir-alex-karp.html |access-date=2020-11-02|issn=0362-4331}}</ref> Nathan Gettings, Joe Lonsdale, [[Stephen Cohen (entrepreneur)|Stephen Cohen]], and [[Alex Karp]] in 2003. The company's name is derived from ''[[The Lord of the Rings]]'' where the magical ''[[palantíri]]'' were "seeing-stones," described as indestructible balls of crystal used for communication and to see events in other parts of the world.

The company, built with CIA funding,<ref>{{Cite news |date=2018-05-08 |title=Peter Thiel and Palantir Are at the Heart of the Iran Nuclear Deal |language=en |work=Bloomberg.com |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-05-08/peter-thiel-in-eye-of-iran-storm-as-deadline-looms-for-trump |access-date=2023-05-28}}</ref> is known for three projects in particular: Palantir Gotham, Palantir Apollo, and Palantir Foundry. Palantir Gotham is used by [[counter-terrorism]] analysts at offices in the [[United States Intelligence Community]] (USIC) and [[United States Department of Defense]].<ref>{{Cite news |date=2020-02-25 |title=Peter Thiel's Palantir Wins Role in $823 Million Government Contract |language=en |publisher=Bloomberg |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-02-25/peter-thiel-s-palantir-wins-role-in-823-million-government-contract |url-status=live |access-date=2020-03-18 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201028133234/https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-02-25/peter-thiel-s-palantir-wins-role-in-823-million-government-contract |archive-date=2020-10-28}}</ref> In the past, Gotham was used by fraud investigators at the [[Recovery Accountability and Transparency Board]], a former US federal agency which operated from 2009 to 2015. Gotham was also used by cyber analysts at [[Information Warfare Monitor]], a Canadian public-private venture which operated from 2003 to 2012. Palantir Apollo is the operating system for continuous delivery and deployment across all environments.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Apollo {{!}} Palantir |url=https://www.palantir.com/platforms/apollo/|access-date=2021-12-14 |publisher=www.palantir.com}}</ref> Their SaaS is one of five offerings authorized for Mission Critical National Security Systems (IL5) by the U.S. Department of Defense.<ref name="bare_url" /><ref name="npr" /> Palantir Foundry is used by corporate clients such as [[Morgan Stanley]], [[Merck KGaA]], [[Airbus]], [[Wejo]], [[Lilium GmbH|Lilium]], and [[Fiat Chrysler Automobiles]].<ref>{{Cite news |date=2019-01-16 |title=Palantir Posted Nearly $1 Billion in 2018 Sales, Executive Says |department=Bloomberg.com |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2019-01-16/palantir-posted-nearly-1-billion-in-2018-sales-executive-says |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201028133233/https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2019-01-16/palantir-posted-nearly-1-billion-in-2018-sales-executive-says |archive-date=2020-10-28 |access-date=2019-02-21 |publisher=Bloomberg}}</ref>

Palantir's original clients were federal agencies of the [[United States Intelligence Community|USIC]]. It has since expanded its customer base to serve state and local governments, as well as private companies in the financial and healthcare industries.<ref name="historypalantir" />

==History==

===2003–2008: Founding and early years===
[[File:Peter Thiel TechCrunch50.jpg|thumb|right|200px|Founder and chairman [[Peter Thiel]] was Palantir's largest shareholder as of late 2014.]]
Though usually listed as having been founded in 2004, [[U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission|SEC]] filings state Palantir's official incorporation to be in May 2003 by [[Peter Thiel]] (co-founder of [[PayPal]]), who named the start-up after the "[[Palantír|seeing stone]]" in [[Tolkien's legendarium]].<ref name="historypalantir">{{Cite web |date=April 2014 |title=A (Pretty) Complete History of Palantir |url=http://www.mausstrategicconsulting.com/1/post/2014/04/a-pretty-complete-history-of-palantir.html |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140516035733/http://www.mausstrategicconsulting.com/1/post/2014/04/a-pretty-complete-history-of-palantir.html |archive-date=16 May 2014 |publisher=Maus Strategic Consulting}}</ref> Thiel saw Palantir as a "mission-oriented company" which could apply software similar to PayPal's fraud recognition systems to "reduce terrorism while preserving civil liberties."<ref>{{Cite web |last1=Greenberg |first1=Andy |last2=Mac |first2=Ryan |date=August 14, 2013 |title=How A 'Deviant' Philosopher Built Palantir, A CIA-Funded Data-Mining Juggernaut |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/andygreenberg/2013/08/14/agent-of-intelligence-how-a-deviant-philosopher-built-palantir-a-cia-funded-data-mining-juggernaut/ |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150604110616/http://www.forbes.com/sites/andygreenberg/2013/08/14/agent-of-intelligence-how-a-deviant-philosopher-built-palantir-a-cia-funded-data-mining-juggernaut/ |archive-date=June 4, 2015 |access-date=September 7, 2017 |website=Forbes}}</ref>

In 2004, Thiel bankrolled the creation of a prototype by [[PayPal]] engineer Nathan Gettings and [[Stanford University]] students Joe Lonsdale and [[Stephen Cohen (entrepreneur)|Stephen Cohen]]. That same year, Thiel hired [[Alex Karp]], a former colleague of his from [[Stanford Law School]], as [[chief executive officer]].<ref>{{Cite web |title=charlierose |url=http://media.palantirtech.com/videos/charlierose.html |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120201172817/http://media.palantirtech.com/videos/charlierose.html |archive-date=2012-02-01 |access-date=2012-01-30 |publisher=Media.palantirtech.com}}</ref>

Headquartered in [[Palo Alto, California]], the company initially struggled to find investors. According to Karp, [[Sequoia Capital]] chairman [[Michael Moritz]] doodled through an entire meeting, and a [[Kleiner Perkins]] executive lectured the founders about the inevitable failure of their company.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Contact information |url=http://www.palantir.com/contact |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130906171806/http://www.palantir.com/contact/ |archive-date=2013-09-06 |access-date=2013-09-10}}</ref> The only early investments were $2 million from the U.S. [[Central Intelligence Agency]]'s venture capital arm [[In-Q-Tel]], and $30 million from Thiel himself and his venture capital firm, [[Founders Fund]].<ref name="bare_url">{{Cite news |last=Gorman |first=Siobhan |date=September 4, 2009 |title=How Team of Geeks Cracked Spy Trade |work=The Wall Street Journal |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB125200842406984303 |url-status=live |access-date=August 8, 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190416223431/https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB125200842406984303 |archive-date=April 16, 2019}}</ref><ref name="npr">{{Cite news |title=A Tech Fix For Illegal Government Snooping? |newspaper = NPR.org|url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=106479613 |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201028133306/https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=106479613 |archive-date=2020-10-28 |access-date=2012-01-30 |publisher=NPR}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |title=Palantir |url=http://www.foundersfund.com/palantir.php |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101123102243/http://foundersfund.com/palantir.php |archive-date=2010-11-23 |access-date=2012-01-30 |publisher=Founders Fund}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |last=Rusli |first=Evelyn |date=2010-06-25 |title=Palantir: The Next Billion-Dollar Company Raises $90 Million |url=https://techcrunch.com/2010/06/25/palantir-the-next-billion-dollar-company-raises-90-million/ |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201028133306/https://techcrunch.com/2010/06/25/palantir-the-next-billion-dollar-company-raises-90-million/ |archive-date=2020-10-28 |access-date=2012-01-30 |publisher=TechCrunch}}</ref><ref name="charlierose">{{Cite web |date=2009-08-11 |title=Alexander Karp |url=http://www.charlierose.com/guest/view/6717 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120104202715/http://www.charlierose.com/guest/view/6717 |archive-date=2012-01-04 |access-date=2012-01-30 |publisher=Charlie Rose}}</ref>

Palantir developed its technology by computer scientists and analysts from intelligence agencies over three years, through pilots facilitated by In-Q-Tel.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Widman |first=Jeff |date=2009-06-05 |title=Palantir keeps it lean and mean on five-year journey from zero to 150 employees |url=https://venturebeat.com/2009/06/05/palantir-keeps-it-lean-and-mean-on-five-year-journey-from-zero-to-150-employees/ |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120303074455/http://venturebeat.com/2009/06/05/palantir-keeps-it-lean-and-mean-on-five-year-journey-from-zero-to-150-employees/ |archive-date=2012-03-03 |access-date=2012-01-30 |publisher=VentureBeat}}</ref><ref name="bare_url" /> The company stated computers alone using [[artificial intelligence]] could not defeat an adaptive adversary. Instead, Palantir proposed using human analysts to explore data from many sources, called [[Intelligence amplification|intelligence augmentation]].<ref>{{Cite web |last=Gesher |first=Ari |date=2010-03-08 |title=Friction in Human-Computer Symbiosis: Kasparov on Chess |url=http://blog.palantirtech.com/2010/03/08/friction-in-human-computer-symbiosis-kasparov-on-chess/ |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120414224548/http://blog.palantirtech.com/2010/03/08/friction-in-human-computer-symbiosis-kasparov-on-chess/ |archive-date=2012-04-14 |access-date=2012-01-30 |publisher=Palantir tech}}</ref>

===2009: GhostNet and the Shadow Network ===
In 2009 and 2010 respectively, [[Information Warfare Monitor]] used Palantir software to uncover the [[GhostNet]] and the [[Shadow Network]]. The GhostNet was a China-based cyber espionage network targeting  1,295 computers in 103 countries, including the [[Dalai Lama]]’s office, a [[NATO]] computer and  various national embassies.<ref>{{Cite news |title=Video |work=CNN |url=http://www.cnn.com/video/#/video/tech/2009/03/30/vause.china.cyber.espionage.cnn |url-status=live |access-date=2010-06-26 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20000816030234/http://www.cnn.com/video/#/video/tech/2009/03/30/vause.china.cyber.espionage.cnn |archive-date=2000-08-16}}</ref> The Shadow Network was also a China-based espionage operation that hacked into the Indian security and defense apparatus. Cyber spies stole documents related to Indian security and NATO troop activity in Afghanistan.<ref name="bare_url_a" /><ref name="Markoff">{{Cite news |last=Markoff |first=John |date=March 29, 2009 |title=Vast Spy System Loots Computers in 103 Countries |work=The New York Times |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/03/29/technology/29spy.html |url-status=live |access-date=February 25, 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090401224950/http://www.nytimes.com/2009/03/29/technology/29spy.html |archive-date=April 1, 2009}}</ref>

===2010–2012: Expansion===
In April 2010, Palantir announced a partnership with [[Thomson Reuters]] to sell the Palantir Metropolis product as "QA Studio" (a [[Quantitative research|quantitative analysis]] tool).<ref>{{Cite news |date=2010-04-12 |title=Press release: Thomson Reuters and Palantir Technologies enter exclusive agreement to create next-generation analytics platform for financial clients |publisher=Thomson Reuters |url=http://thomsonreuters.com/content/press_room/financial/2010_04_12_palantir_technologies_agreement |url-status=dead |access-date=2013-05-27 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120508172659/http://thomsonreuters.com/content/press_room/financial/2010_04_12_palantir_technologies_agreement |archive-date=2012-05-08}}</ref>
On June 18, 2010, [[Vice President of the United States|Vice President]] [[Joe Biden]] and [[Office of Management and Budget]] Director [[Peter Orszag]] held a press conference at the [[White House]] announcing the success of fighting fraud in the stimulus by the [[Recovery Accountability and Transparency Board]] (RATB).  Biden credited the success to the software, Palantir, being deployed by the federal government.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Kauffman |first=Tim |date=2010-06-27 |title=The new high-tech weapons against fraud |url=http://www.federaltimes.com/article/20100627/AGENCY05/6270306/ |access-date=2012-01-30 |publisher=Federal Times}}</ref>  He announced that the capability will be deployed at other government agencies, starting with [[Medicare (United States)|Medicare]] and [[Medicaid]].<ref>{{Cite news |last=Kiely |first=Kathy |date=2010-06-18 |title=Obama administration to create 'do not pay' list to bar shady contractors |work=USA Today |url=http://content.usatoday.com/communities/theoval/post/2010/06/obama-administration-to-create-do-not-pay-list-to-bar-shady-contractors/1 |url-status=live |access-date=2010-06-22 |archive-url=https://archive.today/20120707074408/http://content.usatoday.com/communities/theoval/post/2010/06/obama-administration-to-create-do-not-pay-list-to-bar-shady-contractors/1 |archive-date=2012-07-07}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |last=Orszag |first=Peter |date=2010-06-18 |title=Do Not Pay? Do Read This Post |url=https://obamawhitehouse.archives.gov/omb/blog/10/06/18/Do-Not-Pay-Do-Read-This-Post |via=[[NARA|National Archives]] |work=[[Office of Management and Budget]] |access-date=2012-01-30 }}</ref><ref name="bare_url_b">{{Cite news |last=Kuhn |first=Eric |date=June 1, 2010 |title=Companies capitalize on 'open government' |work=Political Ticker blog |publisher=CNN |url=http://politicalticker.blogs.cnn.com/2010/06/01/companies-capitalize-on-open-government |url-status=live |access-date=September 28, 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201028133315/https://www.cnn.com/politics |archive-date=October 28, 2020}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |date=2010-05-04 |title=Using Palantir with Open Source Data: Finding and Preventing Fraud in Stimulus Spending |url=http://www.palantir.com/2010/05/govcon5-videos-now-available/ |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131110163329/http://www.palantir.com/2010/05/govcon5-videos-now-available/ |archive-date=2013-11-10 |access-date=2013-05-27 |publisher=Palantir Technologies}}</ref>

Estimates were $250 million in revenues in 2011.<ref>{{Cite news |last1=Vance |first1=Ashlee |last2=Stone |first2=Brad |date=November 22, 2011 |title=Palantir, the War on Terror's Secret Weapon: A Silicon Valley startup that collates threats has quietly become indispensable to the U.S. intelligence community |work=Business Week Magazine |url=http://www.businessweek.com/magazine/palantir-the-vanguard-of-cyberterror-security-11222011.html |url-status=dead |access-date=September 28, 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130218194544/http://www.businessweek.com/magazine/palantir-the-vanguard-of-cyberterror-security-11222011.html |archive-date=February 18, 2013}}</ref>

===2013–2016: Additional funding===
{|class="toccolours" style="float: right; margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 0em; font-size: 85%; background:offwhite; color:black; width:30em; max-width: 60%;" cellspacing="5"
|style="text-align: left;"|"[As of 2013] the U.S. spy agencies also employed Palantir to connect databases across departments. Before this, most of the databases used by the CIA and FBI were [[Information silo|siloed]], forcing users to search each database individually. Now everything is linked together using Palantir."
|-
|style="text-align: left;"|— [[TechCrunch]] in January 2015<ref name="tebtecnchrun" />
|}
A document leaked to [[TechCrunch]] revealed that Palantir's clients as of 2013 included at least twelve groups within the U.S. government, including the [[Central Intelligence Agency|CIA]], the [[United States Department of Homeland Security|DHS]], the [[National Security Agency|NSA]], the [[Federal Bureau of Investigation|FBI]], the [[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention|CDC]], the [[United States Marine Corps|Marine Corps]], the [[United States Air Force|Air Force]], the [[United States Special Operations Command|Special Operations Command]], the [[West Point|United States Military Academy]], the [[Joint Improvised-Threat Defeat Organization]] and Allies, the [[Recovery Accountability and Transparency Board]] and the [[National Center for Missing and Exploited Children]]. However, at the time, the [[United States Army]] continued to use its own data analysis tool.<ref name="tebtecnchrun" /> Also, according to [[TechCrunch]], the U.S. spy agencies such as the CIA and FBI were linked for the first time with Palantir software, as their databases had previously been "[[Information silo|siloed]]."<ref name="tebtecnchrun" />

In September 2013, Palantir disclosed over $196 million in funding according to a U.S. [[Securities and Exchange Commission]] filing.<ref>{{Cite web |date=September 27, 2013 |title=Notice of Exempt Offering of Securities |url=https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/1321655/000132165513000002/xslFormDX01/primary_doc.xml |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201028133312/https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/1321655/000132165513000002/xslFormDX01/primary_doc.xml |archive-date=October 28, 2020 |access-date=September 28, 2013 |publisher=The United States Securities and Exchange Commission}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |last=Cutler |first=Kim-Mai |title=Palantir Is Raising $197M In Growth Capital, SEC Filing Shows |date=28 September 2013 |url=https://techcrunch.com/2013/09/27/palantir-197m-sec-filing/ |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201028133316/https://techcrunch.com/2013/09/27/palantir-197m-sec-filing/ |archive-date=2020-10-28 |access-date=2017-06-25 |publisher=TechCrunch}}</ref> It was estimated that the company would likely close almost $1 billion in contracts in 2014.<ref>{{Cite news |last1=Greenberg |first1=Andy |last2=Mac |first2=Ryan |date=September 2, 2013 |title=How A 'Deviant' Philosopher Built Palantir, A CIA-Funded Data-Mining Juggernaut |work=Forbes |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/andygreenberg/2013/08/14/agent-of-intelligence-how-a-deviant-philosopher-built-palantir-a-cia-funded-data-mining-juggernaut/ |url-status=live |access-date=September 28, 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150604110616/http://www.forbes.com/sites/andygreenberg/2013/08/14/agent-of-intelligence-how-a-deviant-philosopher-built-palantir-a-cia-funded-data-mining-juggernaut/ |archive-date=June 4, 2015}}</ref> CEO [[Alex Karp]] announced in 2013 that the company would not be pursuing an [[IPO]], as going public would make "running a company like ours very difficult."<ref name="teafunding" /> In December 2013, the company began a round of financing, raising around $450 million from private funders.  This raised the company's value to $9 billion, according to ''[[Forbes]]'', with the magazine further explaining that the valuation made Palantir "among Silicon Valley’s most valuable private technology companies."<ref name="teafunding" />

In December 2014, ''Forbes'' reported that Palantir was looking to raise $400 million in an additional round of financing, after the company filed paperwork with the [[Securities and Exchange Commission]] the month before. The report was based on research by VC Experts.  If completed, ''Forbes'' stated Palantir's funding could reach a total of $1.2 billion.<ref name="teafunding" /> As of December 2014, the company continued to have diverse private funders, [[Ken Langone]] and [[Stanley Druckenmiller]], [[In-Q-Tel]] of the CIA,<ref name="IranNuclearDeal">{{Cite news |last=Tirone |first=Jonathan |date=2018-05-08 |title=Peter Thiel and Palantir Are at the Heart of the Iran Nuclear Deal |work=Bloomberg.com |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-05-08/peter-thiel-in-eye-of-iran-storm-as-deadline-looms-for-trump |access-date=2018-05-08|quote=Palantir, which Thiel and his partners built with CIA funding}}</ref> [[Tiger Global Management]], and [[Founders Fund]], which is a venture Firm operated by [[Peter Thiel]], the chairman of Palantir. As of December 2014, Thiel was Palantir's largest shareholder.<ref name="teafunding" />

The company was valued at $15 billion in November 2014.<ref>{{Citation |title=Palantir raising more money after tagged with 15 billion valuation |date=January 16, 2015 |url=https://blogs.wsj.com/digits/2015/01/16/palantir-raising-more-money-after-tagged-with-15-billion-valuation/ |work=The Wall Street Journal |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201028133334/https://www.wsj.com/articles/BL-DGB-39945 |access-date=August 4, 2017 |archive-date=October 28, 2020 |url-status=live}}.</ref> In June 2015, [[BuzzFeed]] reported the company was raising up to $500 million in new capital at a valuation of $20 billion.<ref>{{Cite news |last=Alden |first=William |date=June 23, 2015 |title=Palantir Valued At $20 Billion In New Funding Round |publisher=[[BuzzFeed]] |url=https://www.buzzfeed.com/williamalden/palantir-valued-at-20-billion-in-new-funding-round |url-status=live |access-date=June 23, 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150624110755/http://www.buzzfeed.com/williamalden/palantir-valued-at-20-billion-in-new-funding-round |archive-date=June 24, 2015}}</ref> By December 2015, it had raised a further $880 million, while the company was still valued at $20 billion.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Buhr |first=Sarah |date=December 23, 2015 |title=Palantir Has Raised $880 Million At A $20 Billion Valuation |url=https://techcrunch.com/2015/12/23/palantir-has-raised-880-million-at-a-20-billion-valuation/ |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170129143026/https://techcrunch.com/2015/12/23/palantir-has-raised-880-million-at-a-20-billion-valuation/ |archive-date=January 29, 2017 |access-date=December 15, 2016 |publisher=[[TechCrunch]]}}</ref> In February 2016, Palantir bought Kimono Labs, a startup which makes it easy to collect information from public facing websites.<ref>{{cite web |last=Yeung |first=Ken |date=15 February 2016 |title=Palantir acquires Kimono Labs, will shutter data collection service on February 29 |url=https://venturebeat.com/business/palantir-acquires-kimono-labs-will-shutter-data-collection-service-on-february-29/ |website=[[VentureBeat]] |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230502015539/https://venturebeat.com/business/palantir-acquires-kimono-labs-will-shutter-data-collection-service-on-february-29/ |archive-date=2 May 2023 |url-status=live}}</ref>

In August 2016, Palantir acquired [[data visualization]] startup Silk.<ref>{{Cite news |last=Condon |first=Stephanie |title=Palantir acquires data visualization startup Silk |url=http://www.zdnet.com/article/palantir-acquires-data-visualization-startup-silk/ |url-status=live |access-date=10 August 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201028133349/https://www.zdnet.com/article/palantir-acquires-data-visualization-startup-silk/ |archive-date=28 October 2020}}</ref>

===2020===
Palantir is one of four large technology firms<ref>{{Cite news |last=Kelion |first=Leo |date=2020-03-28 |title=NHS turns to big tech to tackle Covid-19 hot spots |language=en-GB |work=BBC News |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/technology-52079287 |url-status=live |access-date=2020-03-29 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201028133336/https://www.bbc.com/news/technology-52079287 |archive-date=2020-10-28}}</ref> to start working with the [[NHS]] on supporting [[COVID-19]] efforts through the provision of software from Palantir Foundry<ref>{{Cite web |title=The power of data in a pandemic - Technology in the NHS |url=https://healthtech.blog.gov.uk/2020/03/28/the-power-of-data-in-a-pandemic/ |access-date=2020-03-29 |website=healthtech.blog.gov.uk |language=en}}</ref> and by April 2020 several countries have used Palantir technology to track and contain the contagion.<ref name="NYT (21 Oct 2020)">{{Cite web |last=Steinberger |first=Michael |author-link=Michael Steinberger |date=21 October 2020 |title=Does Palantir See Too Much? |url=https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/10/21/magazine/palantir-alex-karp.html |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201028133336/https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/10/21/magazine/palantir-alex-karp.html |archive-date=28 October 2020 |access-date=26 October 2020 |website=The New York Times}}</ref>  Palantir also developed Tiberius, a software for vaccine allocation used in the United States.<ref>{{Cite news|last1=Parker|first1=Ashley|last2=Stanley-Becker|first2=Isaac|last3=Linskey|first3=Annie|title=10 days of struggle: Inside Biden's early coronavirus vaccine effort|language=en-US|newspaper=Washington Post|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/biden-vaccine-coronavirus/2021/01/30/eb318c5c-618d-11eb-9061-07abcc1f9229_story.html|access-date=2021-01-31|issn=0190-8286}}</ref>

In December 2020, Palantir was awarded a $44.4 million contract by the U.S. [[Food and Drug Administration]], boosting its shares by about 21%.<ref>{{Cite news|last=O’Donnell|first=Carl|date=2020-12-07|title=Palantir wins $44 million FDA contract, boosting shares 21%|language=en|work=Reuters|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-palantir-tech-fda-idUSKBN28H2TH|access-date=2020-12-08}}</ref>

===Valuation===
The company was valued at $9 billion in early 2014, with ''[[Forbes]]'' stating that the valuation made Palantir "among [[Silicon Valley]]'s most valuable private technology companies".<ref name="teafunding" /> As of December 2014, Thiel was Palantir's largest shareholder.<ref name="teafunding" /> In January 2015, the company was valued at $15 billion after an undisclosed round of funding with $50 million in November 2014.<ref>{{Cite web |title=SEC FORM D |url=https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/1321655/000132165514000005/xslFormDX01/primary_doc.xml |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150725112845/http://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/1321655/000132165514000005/xslFormDX01/primary_doc.xml |archive-date=2015-07-25 |access-date=2015-05-31 |publisher=[[Securities and Exchange Commission]]}}</ref> This valuation rose to $20 billion in late 2015 as the company closed an $880 million round of funding.<ref name="20billion">{{Cite web |last=Buhr |first=Sarah |date=December 23, 2015 |title=Palantir Has Raised $880 Million At A $20 Billion Valuation |url=https://techcrunch.com/2015/12/23/palantir-has-raised-880-million-at-a-20-billion-valuation/ |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170129143026/https://techcrunch.com/2015/12/23/palantir-has-raised-880-million-at-a-20-billion-valuation/ |archive-date=January 29, 2017 |access-date=December 15, 2016 |website=[[TechCrunch]]}}</ref> Palantir has never reported a profit. In 2018, [[Morgan Stanley]] valued the company at $6 billion.<ref>{{Cite news |title=Palantir Knows Everything About You |newspaper=Bloomberg.com |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/features/2018-palantir-peter-thiel/ |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180423171957/https://www.bloomberg.com/features/2018-palantir-peter-thiel/ |archive-date=23 April 2018 |access-date=23 April 2018 |publisher=Bloomberg|last1=Waldman |first1=Peter |last2=Chapman |first2=Lizette |last3=April 19 |first3=Jordan Robertson }}</ref>

Karp, Palantir's [[chief executive officer]], announced in 2013 that the company would not pursue an [[IPO]], as going public would make "running a company like ours very difficult".<ref name="teafunding" /> However, on October 18, 2018, the ''[[Wall Street Journal]]'' reported that Palantir was considering an IPO in the first half of 2019 following a $41 billion valuation.<ref>{{Cite news |last=Copeland |first=Rob |date=2018-10-18 |title=Secretive Data Company Palantir Weighs Giant Public Offering |language=en-US |work=Wall Street Journal |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/secretive-data-company-palantir-weighs-giant-public-offering-1539864003 |url-status=live |access-date=2018-10-19 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181018221959/https://www.wsj.com/articles/secretive-data-company-palantir-weighs-giant-public-offering-1539864003 |archive-date=2018-10-18 |issn=0099-9660}}</ref> In July 2020, it was revealed the company had filed for an IPO.<ref>{{Cite news |last1=Korosec |first1=Kirsten |last2=Whittaker |first2=Zack |last3=Mascarenhas |first3=Natasha |date=7 July 2020 |title=Secretive data startup Palantir has confidentially filed for an IPO |work=TechCrunch |url=https://techcrunch.com/2020/07/06/secretive-data-startup-palantir-has-confidentially-filed-for-an-ipo/ |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200707025625/https://techcrunch.com/2020/07/06/secretive-data-startup-palantir-has-confidentially-filed-for-an-ipo/ |archive-date=7 July 2020}}</ref>

It ultimately went public on the New York Stock Exchange through a [[direct public offering]] on September 30, 2020 under the ticker symbol "PLTR".<ref name="Kindig 2020">{{cite web | last=Kindig | first=Beth | title=Palantir IPO: Deep-Dive Analysis | website=Forbes | date=2020-09-29 | url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/bethkindig/2020/09/29/palantir-ipo-deep-dive-analysis/ | access-date=2020-11-09}}</ref>

===Investments===
The company has invested over $400 million into nearly two dozen [[Special-purpose acquisition company|SPAC]] targets according to investment bank [[RBC Capital Markets]], while bringing alongside those companies as customers.<ref>{{cite web| title=Palantir has pumped over $400 million into SPACs and boosted its revenues at the same time.| website=Forbes| date=2021-11-24| url=https://fortune.com/2021/11/24/palantir-spac-investments-wall-street-questions/| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211124163227/https://fortune.com/2021/11/24/palantir-spac-investments-wall-street-questions/| archive-date=2021-11-24}}</ref>

==Products==

===Palantir Gotham===
Palantir Gotham is Palantir's government offering. It is an evolution of Palantir's longstanding work in the [[United States Intelligence Community]]. More recently, Palantir Gotham has been used as a [[predictive policing]] system, which has elicited some controversy over racism in their AI analytics.<ref name="AP Pushback" >{{cite news |last1=Neslen |first1=Arthur |title=FEATURE-Pushback against AI policing in Europe heats up over racism fears |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/europe-tech-police-idINL8N2R92HQ |website=www.reuters.com |date=20 October 2021 |agency=Reuters |access-date=1 November 2021}}</ref>

===Palantir Metropolis===
Palantir Metropolis (formerly known as Palantir Finance) was<ref>{{Cite news |title=Palantir Stops Mocking Salespeople and Starts Hiring Them |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2019-01-07/palantir-is-said-to-hire-salespeople-it-once-mocked-as-ipo-nears |access-date=2019-02-28 |newspaper=Bloomberg.com|date=7 January 2019 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |last=Chapman |first=Lizette |title=Palantir once mocked the idea of salespeople. Now it's hiring them |url=https://www.latimes.com/business/la-fi-palantir-sales-ipo-20190107-story.html |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201028133337/https://www.latimes.com/business/la-fi-palantir-sales-ipo-20190107-story.html |archive-date=2020-10-28 |access-date=2019-02-28 |website=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=7 January 2019 }}</ref> software for [[data integration]], [[information management]] and quantitative [[analytics]].  The software connects to commercial, proprietary and [[public data]] sets and discovers trends, relationships and anomalies, including [[predictive analytics]].<ref name="Bloomberg180419Waldman">{{Cite news |last1=Waldman |first1=Peter |last2=Chapman |first2=Lizette |last3=Robertson |first3=Jordan |date=April 19, 2018 |title=Peter Thiel's data-mining company is using War on Terror tools to track American citizens. The scary thing? Palantir is desperate for new customers. |publisher=Bloomberg |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/features/2018-palantir-peter-thiel/ |url-status=live |access-date=April 24, 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201028133337/https://www.bloomberg.com/features/2018-palantir-peter-thiel/ |archive-date=October 28, 2020}}</ref><ref name="Bloomberg180419Mak">{{Cite news |last=Mak |first=Aaron |date=April 19, 2018 |title=Report: Palantir Helped JPMorgan Spy on Employees |publisher=Bloomberg |url=https://slate.com/technology/2018/04/jpmorgan-used-palantir-tools-monitor-employee-activity-bloomberg-report.html |url-status=live |access-date=April 24, 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201028133337/https://slate.com/technology/2018/04/jpmorgan-used-palantir-tools-monitor-employee-activity-bloomberg-report.html |archive-date=October 28, 2020}}</ref> Aided by 120 "forward-deployed engineers" of Palantir during 2009, Peter Cavicchia III of JPMorgan used Metropolis to monitor employee communications and alert the insider threat team when an employee showed any signs of potential disgruntlement: the insider alert team would further scrutinize the employee and possibly conduct physical surveillance after hours with bank security personnel.<ref name=Bloomberg180419Waldman/><ref name=Bloomberg180419Mak/> The Metropolis team used emails, download activity, browser histories, and GPS locations from JPMorgan owned smartphones and their transcripts of digitally recorded phone conversations to search, aggregate, sort, and analyze this information for any specific keywords, phrases, and patterns of behavior.<ref name=Bloomberg180419Waldman/><ref name=Bloomberg180419Mak/> In 2013, Cavicchia may have shared this information with [[Frank Bisignano]] who had become the CEO of [[First Data Corporation]].<ref name=Bloomberg180419Waldman/>

=== Palantir Apollo ===
Palantir Apollo is a continuous delivery system that manages and deploys Palantir Gotham and Foundry.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Palantir |date=2020-10-08 |title=Palantir Apollo: Powering SaaS where no SaaS has gone before |url=https://medium.com/palantir/palantir-apollo-powering-saas-where-no-saas-has-gone-before-7be3e565c379 |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201019183817/https://medium.com/palantir/palantir-apollo-powering-saas-where-no-saas-has-gone-before-7be3e565c379 |archive-date=2020-10-19 |access-date=2020-10-19 |website=Medium |language=en}}</ref> Apollo was built out of the need for customers to use multiple public and private cloud platforms as part of their infrastructure. Apollo orchestrates updates to configurations and software in the Foundry and Gotham platforms using a [[Microservices|micro-service]] architecture. This product allows Palantir to provide software as a service ([[Software as a service|SaaS]]) rather than to operate as a consulting company.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Cash |first=Mark |title=Peering into Palantir's Data Market Disruption |url=https://www.morningstar.ca/ca/news/205897/peering-into-palantirs-data-market-disruption.aspx <!-- while certain archive services have attempted to take snapshots of this page, the website itself redirects all such attempts to the home page, although the page itself is still online for now --> |access-date=2020-10-19 |website=Morningstar CA |language=en }}</ref>

===Palantir Foundry ===
Palantir Foundry was used by [[NHS England]] in dealing with the [[COVID-19 pandemic in England]] to analyze the operation of the vaccination program. A campaign was started against the company in June 2021 by Foxglove, a tech-justice nonprofit, because "Their background has generally been in contracts where people are harmed, not healed." [[Clive Lewis MP]], supporting the campaign said Palantir had an "appalling track record."<ref name="CNBC">{{cite news |title=Campaign launches to try to force Palantir out of Britain's NHS |url=https://www.cnbc.com/2021/06/04/campaign-launched-to-get-palantir-out-of-nhs.html |access-date=16 June 2021 |publisher=CNBC |date=4 June 2021}}</ref>

Foundry is also used for the administration of the UK [[Homes for Ukraine]] program.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Palantir for UK Government|url=https://www.palantir.com/uk/government/|access-date=2022-11-13 |website=Palantir|language=en }}</ref>  It gives caseworkers employed by local authorities access to data held by the [[Department for Levelling Up, Housing and Communities]], some of which is supplied by the UK [[Home Office]].

===Other===
The company has been involved in a number of business and consumer products, designing in part or in whole. For example, in 2014, they premiered Insightics, which according to the ''[[Wall Street Journal]] '' "extracts customer spending and demographic information from merchants’ [[Credit history|credit-card records]]." It was created in tandem with credit processing company [[First Data]].<ref name="tezfirstprofit">{{Cite news |last=Sidel |first=Robin |date=February 10, 2015 |title=First Data Reports First Quarterly Profit in More Than Seven Years |work=[[Wall Street Journal]] |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/first-data-reports-first-quarterly-profit-in-more-than-seven-years-1423602902 |url-status=live |access-date=2015-02-25 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201028133338/https://www.wsj.com/articles/first-data-reports-first-quarterly-profit-in-more-than-seven-years-1423602902 |archive-date=2020-10-28}}</ref>

In April 2023, the company launched Artificial Intelligence Platform (AIP) which integrates [[large language model]]s into privately operated networks. The company demonstrated its use in war, where a military operator was able to deploy operations and receive responses via an AI [[chatbot]].<ref>{{cite web |last=Gault |first=Matthew |date=April 26, 2023 |title=Palantir Demos AI to Fight Wars But Says It Will Be Totally Ethical Don’t Worry About It |url=https://www.vice.com/en/article/qjvb4x/palantir-demos-ai-to-fight-wars-but-says-it-will-be-totally-ethical-dont-worry-about-it |website=[[Vice (magazine)|Vince]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last=Tarantola |first=Andrew |date=April 26, 2023 |title=Palantir shows off an AI that can go to war |url=https://www.engadget.com/palantir-shows-off-an-ai-that-can-go-to-war-180513781.html? |website=[[Engadget]]}}</ref> Citing potential risks of [[generative artificial intelligence]], CEO Karp said that the product would not let the AI independently carry out targeting operations, requiring human oversight.<ref>{{cite web |last=Capoot |first=Ashley |date=May 8, 2023 |title=Palantir soars on earnings beat and prediction of full-year profitability
 |url=https://www.cnbc.com/2023/05/08/palantir-earnings-report-q1-2023.html |website=[[CNBC]]}}</ref>

==Customers==

===Corporate use===
{{See also|Information Warfare Monitor}}
Palantir Metropolis is used by hedge funds, banks, and financial services firms.<ref name="bare_url" /><ref name="npr" /><ref name="bare_url_a">{{Cite web |last=Chiang |first=Oliver |date=2010-04-30 |title=PayPal-Based Technology Helped Bust India's And The Dalai Lama's Cyberspies |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/firewall/2010/04/30/paypal-based-technology-helped-bust-indias-and-the-dalai-lamas-cyberspies/ |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170814002848/https://www.forbes.com/sites/firewall/2010/04/30/paypal-based-technology-helped-bust-indias-and-the-dalai-lamas-cyberspies/ |archive-date=2017-08-14 |access-date=2017-09-07 |magazine=Forbes}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |title=A Human Driven Data-centric Approach to Accountability: Analyzing Data to Prevent Fraud, Waste and Abuse in Stimulus Spending: Gov 2.0 Expo 2010 - Co-produced by UBM TechWeb & O'Reilly Conferences, May 25 - 27, 2010, Washington, DC |url=http://www.gov2expo.com/gov2expo2010/public/schedule/detail/13996 |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201028133339/https://www.oreilly.com/conferences/ |archive-date=2020-10-28 |access-date=2012-01-30 |publisher=Gov2expo.com}}</ref>

Palantir Foundry clients include [[Merck KGaA]],<ref>{{Cite web |date=2018-11-20 |title=Merck KGaA, Palantir's new joint venture looks to tear down cancer research data silos |url=https://www.mobihealthnews.com/content/merck-kgaa-palantirs-new-joint-venture-looks-tear-down-cancer-research-data-silos |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201028133339/https://www.mobihealthnews.com/content/merck-kgaa-palantirs-new-joint-venture-looks-tear-down-cancer-research-data-silos |archive-date=2020-10-28 |access-date=2019-02-27 |website=MobiHealthNews |language=en}}</ref> [[Airbus]]<ref>{{Cite web |date=2018-10-23 |title=Airbus believes its AI can eliminate flight delays |url=https://venturebeat.com/2018/10/22/airbus-believes-its-ai-can-eliminate-flight-delays/ |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201028133340/https://venturebeat.com/2018/10/22/airbus-believes-its-ai-can-eliminate-flight-delays/ |archive-date=2020-10-28 |access-date=2019-02-27 |website=VentureBeat |language=en-US}}</ref> and [[Scuderia Ferrari|Ferrari]].<ref>{{Cite web |last=Palantir |title=Palantir Foundry Enables Scuderia Ferrari Through Data |url=https://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/palantir-foundry-enables-scuderia-ferrari-through-data-873451908.html |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201028133340/https://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/palantir-foundry-enables-scuderia-ferrari-through-data-873451908.html |archive-date=2020-10-28 |access-date=2019-02-27 |website=www.prnewswire.com |language=en}}</ref>

Palantir partner [[Information Warfare Monitor]] used Palantir software to uncover both the [[Ghostnet]] and the [[Shadow Network]].<ref name="bare_url_a" /><ref>{{Cite news |title=CNN.com Video |work=CNN |url=http://www.cnn.com/video/#/video/tech/2009/03/30/vause.china.cyber.espionage.cnn |url-status=live |access-date=2010-06-26 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20000816030234/http://www.cnn.com/video/#/video/tech/2009/03/30/vause.china.cyber.espionage.cnn |archive-date=2000-08-16}}</ref><ref name="Markoff"/>

===U.S. civil entities===
Palantir's software is used by the [[Recovery Accountability and Transparency Board]] to detect and investigate fraud and abuse in the [[American Recovery and Reinvestment Act]].  Specifically, the Recovery Operations Center (ROC) used Palantir to integrate transactional data with open-source and private data sets that describe the entities receiving stimulus funds.{{clarify|date=March 2015}}<ref name="bare_url_b" /> Other clients as of 2019 included [[Polaris Project]],<ref>{{Cite web |last=Knox |first=Karin |date=January 24, 2014 |title=How Many Years A Slave? |url=https://www.palantir.com/2014/01/how-many-years-a-slave/ |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304125053/https://www.palantir.com/2014/01/how-many-years-a-slave/ |archive-date=March 4, 2016}}</ref> the [[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention]], the [[National Center for Missing and Exploited Children]],<ref name="tebtecnchrun" /> the [[National Institutes of Health]],<ref>{{Cite web |date=2018-09-24 |title=With $7M contract, NIH taps big data analysis platform Palantir to streamline health research |url=https://www.mobihealthnews.com/content/7m-contract-nih-taps-big-data-analysis-platform-palantir-streamline-health-research |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201028133340/https://www.mobihealthnews.com/content/7m-contract-nih-taps-big-data-analysis-platform-palantir-streamline-health-research |archive-date=2020-10-28 |access-date=2019-02-28 |website=MobiHealthNews |language=en}}</ref> [[Team Rubicon]],<ref>{{Cite news |title=Can Data-Crunching Palantir Find Missing Children and Catch Traffickers? |url=http://fortune.com/2016/03/14/how-palantir-uses-big-data-to-find-missing-kids/ |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201028133342/https://fortune.com/2016/03/14/how-palantir-uses-big-data-to-find-missing-kids/ |archive-date=2020-10-28 |access-date=2019-02-28 |website=Fortune |language=en}}</ref> and the United Nations [[World Food Programme]].<ref>{{Cite web |title=Palantir and WFP partner to help transform global humanitarian delivery {{!}} World Food Programme |url=https://www1.wfp.org/news/palantir-and-wfp-partner-help-transform-global-humanitarian-delivery |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201028133344/https://www.wfp.org/news/palantir-and-wfp-partner-help-transform-global-humanitarian-delivery |archive-date=2020-10-28 |access-date=2019-02-28 |website=www1.wfp.org}}</ref>

In October 2020, Palantir began helping the federal government set up a system that will track the manufacture, distribution and administration of [[Coronavirus disease 2019|COVID-19]] vaccines across the country.<ref>{{Cite news |last=Winkler |first=Peter Loftus and Rolfe |date=2020-10-22 |title=WSJ News Exclusive {{!}} Palantir to Help U.S. Track Covid-19 Vaccines |language=en-US |work=Wall Street Journal |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/palantir-to-help-u-s-track-covid-19-vaccines-11603367276 |url-status=live |access-date=2020-10-23 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201028133343/https://trc.taboola.com/advance-pennlivecom/log/3/visible?tvi2=2512&route=LA%3ALA%3AV&lti=deflated |archive-date=2020-10-28 |issn=0099-9660}}</ref>

===U.S. military, intelligence, and police===
Palantir Gotham is used by counter-terrorism analysts at offices in the [[United States Intelligence Community]] and [[United States Department of Defense]], fraud investigators at the [[Recovery Accountability and Transparency Board]], and cyber analysts at [[Information Warfare Monitor]] (responsible for the [[GhostNet]] and the [[Shadow Network]] investigation).

Other clients as of 2013 included [[DHS]], [[NSA]], [[FBI]], the [[United States Marine Corps|Marine Corps]], the [[United States Air Force|Air Force]], [[United States Special Operations Command|Special Operations Command]], [[West Point]], the [[Joint IED Defeat Organization]] and Allies. However, at the time the [[United States Army]] continued to use its own data analysis tool.<ref name="tebtecnchrun" /> Also, according to [[TechCrunch]], "The U.S. spy agencies also employed Palantir to [[database integration|connect databases]] across departments. Before this, most of the databases used by the CIA and [[FBI]] were [[Information silo|silo]]ed, forcing users to search each database individually. Now everything is linked together using Palantir."<ref name="tebtecnchrun" />

U.S. [[military intelligence]] used the Palantir product to improve their ability to predict locations of [[improvised explosive devices]] in its [[war in Afghanistan (2001–present)|war in Afghanistan]]. A small number of practitioners reported it to be more useful than the United States Army's [[Program of Record]], the [[Distributed Common Ground System]] (DCGS-A). California Congressman [[Duncan D. Hunter]] complained of [[United States Department of Defense]] obstacles to its wider use in 2012.<ref>{{Cite news |last=Scarborough |first=Rowan |author-link=Rowan Scarborough |date=July 16, 2012 |title=Military has to fight to purchase lauded IED buster |work=[[The Washington Times]] |url=http://p.washingtontimes.com/news/2012/jul/16/military-has-to-fight-to-purchase-lauded-ied-buste/ |url-status=live |access-date=September 29, 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120719162415/http://p.washingtontimes.com/news/2012/jul/16/military-has-to-fight-to-purchase-lauded-ied-buste/ |archive-date=July 19, 2012}}</ref>

Palantir has also been reported to be working with various U.S. police departments, for example accepting a contract in 2013 to help the Northern California Regional Intelligence Center build a controversial [[license plate]]s database for California.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Blagdon |first=Jeff |date=June 29, 2013 |title=Palantir is helping California police develop controversial license plate database |url=https://www.theverge.com/2013/6/29/4478748/california-license-plate-reader-database-palantir |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201028133350/https://www.theverge.com/2013/6/29/4478748/california-license-plate-reader-database-palantir |archive-date=October 28, 2020 |access-date=September 7, 2017 |publisher=[[The Verge]]}}</ref> In 2012 [[New Orleans Police Department]] partnered with Palantir to create a predictive policing program.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Winston |first=Ali |date=February 27, 2018 |title=PALANTIR HAS SECRETLY BEEN USING NEW ORLEANS TO TEST ITS PREDICTIVE POLICING TECHNOLOGY |url=https://www.theverge.com/2018/2/27/17054740/palantir-predictive-policing-tool-new-orleans-nopd |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180228150754/https://www.theverge.com/2018/2/27/17054740/palantir-predictive-policing-tool-new-orleans-nopd |archive-date=February 28, 2018 |access-date=February 28, 2018 |publisher=[[The Verge]]}}</ref>

In 2014, [[US Immigration and Customs Enforcement]] (ICE) awarded Palantir a $41 million contract to build and maintain a new intelligence system called Investigative Case Management (ICM) to track personal and criminal records of legal and [[illegal immigrant]]s. This application has originally been conceived by ICE's office of Homeland Security Investigations (HSI), allowing its users access to intelligence platforms maintained by other federal and private law enforcement entities. The system reached its "final operation capacity" under the Trump administration in September 2017.<ref name="DeportationMachine" />

Palantir took over the Pentagon's [[Project Maven]] contract in 2019 after Google decided not to continue developing AI unmanned drones used for bombings and intelligence.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web |date=December 2019 |title=Palantir took over from Google on Project Maven |url=https://www.businessinsider.com/palantir-took-over-from-google-on-project-maven-2019-12 |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201028133358/https://www.businessinsider.com/palantir-took-over-from-google-on-project-maven-2019-12 |archive-date=28 October 2020 |access-date=17 January 2020 |website=Business Insider}}</ref>

===International Atomic Energy Agency===
Palantir was used by the [[International Atomic Energy Agency|International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA)]] to verify if Iran was in compliance with the [[Iran nuclear deal framework|2015 agreement]].<ref name="IranNuclearDeal" />

=== British National Health Service (NHS) ===
The firm has contracts relating to patient data from the British [[National Health Service]]. It was awarded an emergency, no-competition contract to mine COVID-19 patient data in 2019. In 2020 this was valued at more than £23.5 million and was extended for two more years. The awarding of the contract without competition was heavily criticised, prompting the NHS to pledge an open and transparent procurement process for any future data contract.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Times |first=Byline |last2=Hencke |first2=David |date=2020-04-22 |title=Palantir Coronavirus Contract Did Not Go to Competitive Tender |url=https://bylinetimes.com/2020/04/22/palantir-coronavirus-contract-did-not-go-to-competitive-tender/ |access-date=2023-04-14 |website=Byline Times |language=en-GB}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |title=Commentary: We’ve won our lawsuit over UK govt's £23m NHS data deal with Palantir |url=https://www.business-humanrights.org/en/latest-news/commentary-weve-won-our-lawsuit-over-uk-23m-nhs-data-deal-with-palantir/ |access-date=2023-04-14 |website=Business & Human Rights Resource Centre |language=en}}</ref>

The firm was encouraged by [[Liam Fox]] "to expand their software business" in Britain.<ref>{{cite news |date=29 June 2021 |title=UK trade department courted US firm Palantir over 'untapped' NHS data potential |publisher=Politico |url=https://www.politico.eu/article/uk-trade-department-courted-us-firm-palantir-over-untapped-nhs-data-potential/ |access-date=6 July 2021}}</ref>  It was said to be "critical to the success of the vaccination and PPE programmes,” but its involvement in the NHS was controversial among civil liberties groups.<ref>{{cite news |date=9 June 2022 |title=Palantir gears up to expand its reach into UK's NHS |publisher=Financial Times |url=https://www.ft.com/content/3f6f24f8-9e5c-42c3-8ae6-bfef5f953524 |access-date=9 June 2022}}</ref> Conservative MP [[David Davis (British politician)|David Davis]] called for a judicial review into the sharing of patient data with Palantir.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Clark |first=Lindsay |title=Backbench Tory campaigner promises judicial review of data grab of English GP patients unless UK government changes tack |url=https://www.theregister.com/2021/06/25/david_davis_gpdpr/ |access-date=2023-04-14 |website=www.theregister.com |language=en}}</ref>

The procurement of a £480m Federated Data Platform by [[NHS England]], launched in January 2023 has been described as a 'must win' for Palantir.<ref>{{Cite news |date=2022-06-09 |title=Palantir gears up to expand its reach into UK’s NHS |work=Financial Times |url=https://www.ft.com/content/3f6f24f8-9e5c-42c3-8ae6-bfef5f953524 |access-date=2023-03-31}}</ref> The procurement has been described as a "farce" by civil liberties campaigners, alleging that Palantir have a competitive advantage as it "already has its feet under the table in NHS England" and benefits from a short procurement window.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Glaze |first=Ben |date=2023-02-07 |title=Campaigners warning over US tech giant's NHS links as deadline for deal looms |url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/politics/campaigners-warning-over-tech-giants-29154470 |access-date=2023-04-04 |website=mirror |language=en}}</ref> In April 2023 it was revealed that a consortium of UK companies had been unsuccessful in its bid for the contract.<ref>{{Cite web |last=says |first=Basil_Bekdash |date=2023-04-13 |title=UK Consortium unsuccessful in its bid for £480M Federated Data Platform |url=https://www.digitalhealth.net/2023/04/uk-consortium-unsuccessful-in-its-bid-for-480m-federated-data-platform/ |access-date=2023-04-14 |website=Digital Health |language=en-GB}}</ref>

In April 2023, Conservative MP David Davis publicly expressed his concern over the procurement process, stating that it could become a "battle royale". Davis is one of a dozen MPs pressing the government over privacy concerns with the use of data. Labour peer and former Health Minister [[Philip Hunt, Baron Hunt of Kings Heath|Philip Hunt]] voiced his concern about Palantir's use of data, stating “The current NHS and current government doesn’t have a good track record of getting the details right, and the procurement shows no sign of going better.” <ref name="Mason">{{Cite news |last=Mason |first=Rowena |last2=editor |first2=Rowena Mason Whitehall |date=2023-04-27 |title=Ex-minister predicts ‘battle royale’ over US firm’s bid for NHS data contract |language=en-GB |work=The Guardian |url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2023/apr/27/ex-minister-predicts-battle-royale-over-us-firms-bid-for-nhs-data-contract |access-date=2023-04-28 |issn=0261-3077}}</ref>

In April 2023, it was also reported that Palantir had seen eleven pilots of its Foundry system paused by NHS organisations. A spokesperson for the Department of Health and Social Care stated that this was due to "operational issues".<ref name="Mason"/>

In January 2023 Palantir's founder, [[Peter Thiel]], called Britain's affection for the NHS "[[Stockholm syndrome|Stockholm Syndrome]]" during a speech to the [[Oxford Union]], going on to say that the NHS "makes people sick". A Palantir spokesman clarified that Thiel was "speaking as a private individual" and his comments "do not in any way reflect the views of Palantir".<ref>{{Cite news |last=Somerville |first=Ewan |date=2023-01-18 |title=Britain’s affection for the NHS is Stockholm syndrome, says billionaire |language=en-GB |work=The Telegraph |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2023/01/18/peter-thiel-britains-affection-nhs-stockholm-syndrome/ |access-date=2023-03-29 |issn=0307-1235}}</ref>

In March 2023 it was revealed that NHS hospitals had been 'ordered' to share patient data with Palantir, prompting renewed criticism from civil liberties groups.<ref>{{Cite news |last=Amin |first=Ali Mitib, Lucas |title=NHS tells hospitals to share medical records with US spy-tech company |language=en |url=https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/nhs-tells-hospitals-to-share-medical-records-with-us-spy-tech-company-qhs3397ft |access-date=2023-03-31 |issn=0140-0460}}</ref> Campaign groups including the [[The Doctors' Association UK|Doctors' Association UK]], [[National Pensioners Convention|National Pensioners' Convention]], and Just Treatment, subsequently threatened legal action over NHS England's procurement of the FDP contract citing concerns over the use of patient data.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Clark |first=Lindsay |title=NHS threatened with legal action over patient data platform |url=https://www.theregister.com/2023/03/17/nhs_threatened_with_legal_action/ |access-date=2023-03-31 |website=www.theregister.com |language=en}}</ref>

[[NHS England]]'s former artificial intelligence chief, Indra Joshi, was recruited by Palantir in 2022.  The company said they were planning to increase their team in the UK by 250.<ref>{{cite news |date=22 April 2022 |title=NHS's AI chief joins CIA-linked US tech firm |publisher=Health Service Journal |url=https://www.hsj.co.uk/technology-and-innovation/nhss-ai-chief-joins-cia-linked-us-tech-firm/7032331.article |access-date=24 May 2022}}</ref> Palantir's UK head, Louis Moseley, was quoted internally as saying that Palantir's strategy for entry into the British health industry was to "Buy our way in" by hoovering up smaller rival companies with existing relationships with the NHS in order to “take a lot of ground and take down a lot of political resistance.” <ref>{{Cite news |date=2022-09-30 |title=Peter Thiel’s Palantir Had Secret Plan to Crack UK’s NHS: ‘Buying Our Way In’ |language=en |work=Bloomberg.com |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2022-09-30/palantir-had-plan-to-crack-uk-health-system-buying-our-way-in |access-date=2023-04-04}}</ref>

===Europe===
The Danish POL-INTEL predictive policing project has been operational since 2017 and is based on the Gotham system. According to the AP the Danish system "uses a mapping system to build a so-called heat map identifying areas with higher crime rates." The Gotham system has also been used by German state police in Hesse and Europol.<ref name="AP Pushback" />

The Norwegian Customs is using Palantir Gotham to screen passengers and vehicles for control. Known inputs are prefiled freight documents, passenger lists, the national Currency Exchange database (tracks all cross-border currency exchanges), the Norwegian Welfare Administrations employer- and employee-registry, the Norwegian stock holder registry and 30 public databases from InfoTorg. InfoTorg provides access to more than 30 databases, including the Norwegian National Citizen registry, European Business Register, the Norwegian DMV vehicle registry, various credit databases etc. These databases are supplemented by the Norwegian Customs Departments own intelligence reports, including results of previous controls. The system is also augmented by data from public sources such as social media.<ref>{{cite news |title=Norwegian Customs implement new methods to catch smugglers |url=https://www.nettavisen.no/nyheter/dine-venner-og-nettbruk-kan-avgjore-om-du-stoppes-i-tollen/s/12-95-3423409135 |access-date=5 December 2021 |publisher=Nettavisen |date=24 January 2018}}</ref>[[File:Palantir 2022.jpg|thumb|Palantir stand at the NHS Confederation conference 2022]]

==== Ukraine ====
Palantir's technology is used close to the front line. It is used to shorten the "[[kill chain]]" in [[Russo-Ukrainian War]].<ref>{{cite news |last=Ignatius |first=David |author-link=David Ignatius |date=2022-12-19 |title=How the algorithm tipped the balance in Ukraine |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/2022/12/19/palantir-algorithm-data-ukraine-war/ |newspaper=[[The Washington Post]] |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221219195253/https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/2022/12/19/palantir-algorithm-data-ukraine-war/ |archive-date=2022-12-19 |url-status=live}}</ref> [[Prosecutor General of Ukraine|Ukraine's prosecutor general's office]] also planned to utilize Palantir's software to help it prosecute alleged [[war crimes in the Russian invasion of Ukraine]].<ref>{{cite news |last=Wright |first=Ben |date=2023-04-22 |title=The 'all-seeing' tech giant mapping Putin’s war crimes |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/business/2023/04/22/palantir-peter-thiel-putin-war-crimes/ |newspaper=[[The Daily Telegraph]] |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230424094353/https://www.telegraph.co.uk/business/2023/04/22/palantir-peter-thiel-putin-war-crimes/ |archive-date=2023-04-24 |url-status=}}</ref>

==Partnerships and contracts==

===International Business Machines===
On February 8, 2021, Palantir and IBM announced a new partnership that would use IBM's hybrid cloud data platform alongside Palantir's operations platform for building applications. The product, Palantir for IBM Cloud Pak for Data, is expected to simplify the process of building and deploying AI-integrated applications with IBM Watson. It will help businesses/users interpret and use large datasets without needing a strong technical background. Palantir for IBM Cloud Pak for Data will be available for general use in March 2021.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://newsroom.ibm.com/2021-02-08-IBM-and-Palantir-Partner-to-Help-Businesses-Easily-Deploy-Powerful-and-Open-AI-Applications-Unlock-Valuable-Data-Across-Hybrid-Cloud-Environments#assets_all|title=IBM and Palantir Partner to Help Businesses Easily Deploy Powerful and Open AI Applications; Unlock Valuable Data Across Hybrid Cloud Environments}}</ref>

===Amazon (AWS)===
On March 5, 2021, Palantir announced its partnership with Amazon AWS. Palantir's ERP Suite is now optimized to run on [[Amazon Web Services]]. One of the first notable successes of the ERP suite was with [[BP]], which was able to save about $50 million in working capital within two weeks of onboarding the system.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://blog.palantir.com/launching-erp-suite-to-deliver-cost-savings-for-aws-customers-ceed6e6dd927|title = Launching ERP Suite to deliver cost savings for AWS customers|date = 5 March 2021}}</ref>

===Babylon Health===
Palantir took a stake in [[Babylon Health]] in June 2021. [[Ali Parsa]] told the ''[[Financial Times]]'' that "nobody" has brought some of the tech that Palantir owns "into the realm of biology and health care".<ref name="CNBC"/>

==Controversies==

===Algorithm development===
[[I2 Group|i2 Inc]] sued Palantir in Federal Court alleging fraud, conspiracy, and copyright infringement over Palantir's algorithm. Shyam Sankar, Palantir's director of business development, used a [[Private investigator|private eye]] company as the [[Cutout (espionage)|cutout]] for obtaining i2's code. i2 settled out of court for $10 million in 2011.<ref name=Bloomberg180419Waldman/>

===WikiLeaks proposals (2010)===
In 2010, [[Hunton & Williams]] LLP allegedly asked [[Berico Technologies]], Palantir, and [[HBGary Federal]] to draft a response plan to "the [[WikiLeaks]] Threat." In early 2011 [[Anonymous (group)|Anonymous]] publicly released HBGary-internal documents, including the plan. The plan proposed that Palantir software would "serve as the foundation for all the data collection, integration, analysis, and production efforts."<ref name="Harris">{{Cite web |last=Harris |first=Shane |date=31 January 2012 |title=Killer App |url=http://www.washingtonian.com/articles/people/killer-app/ |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201028133450/https://www.washingtonian.com/2012/01/31/killer-app/ |archive-date=28 October 2020 |access-date=14 March 2012 |website=Washingtonian}}</ref>  The plan also included slides, allegedly authored by HBGary CEO Aaron Barr, which suggested "[spreading] disinformation" and "disrupting" [[Glenn Greenwald]]’s support for WikiLeaks.<ref>{{Cite web |last1=Wray |first1=James |last2=Stabe |first2=Ulf |title=Data intelligence firms proposed a systematic attack against WikiLeaks |url=http://www.thetechherald.com/articles/Data-intelligence-firms-proposed-a-systematic-attack-against-WikiLeaks/12751/ |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181126010658/http://www.thetechherald.com/articles/Data-intelligence-firms-proposed-a-systematic-attack-against-WikiLeaks/12751/ |archive-date=2018-11-26 |access-date=2012-01-30 |publisher=Thetechherald.com}}</ref>

Palantir CEO Karp ended all ties to HBGary and issued a statement apologizing to "progressive organizations… and Greenwald … for any involvement that we may have had in these matters." Palantir placed an employee on leave pending a review by a third-party law firm. The employee was later reinstated.<ref name="Harris" />

===Racial discrimination lawsuit (2016)===
On September 26, 2016, the [[Office of Federal Contract Compliance Programs]] of the [[United States Department of Labor|U.S. Department of Labor]] filed a lawsuit against Palantir alleging that the company discriminated against Asian job applicants on the basis of their race.<ref>{{Cite web |title=COMPLAINT FOR VIOLATIONS OF EXECUTIVE ORDER 11246 |url=https://www.dol.gov/sites/default/files/newsroom/newsreleases/OFCCP20160926_0.pdf |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161001163715/https://www.dol.gov/sites/default/files/newsroom/newsreleases/OFCCP20160926_0.pdf |archive-date=2016-10-01 |access-date=2016-09-27 |publisher=[[United States Department of Justice]]}}</ref> According to the lawsuit, the company "routinely eliminated" Asian applicants during the hiring process, even when they were "as qualified as white applicants" for the same jobs.<ref name="vanityfair">{{Cite magazine |last=Kosoff |first=Maya |date=September 27, 2016 |title=U.S. GOVERNMENT SUES PETER THIEL'S SECRETIVE BIG-DATA START-UP FOR DISCRIMINATION |url=http://www.vanityfair.com/news/2016/09/us-government-sues-palantir-discrimination |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161104153529/http://www.vanityfair.com/news/2016/09/us-government-sues-palantir-discrimination |archive-date=November 4, 2016 |access-date=October 31, 2016 |magazine=Vanity Fair}}</ref> Palantir settled the suit in April 2017 for $1.7 million while not admitting wrongdoing.<ref>{{Cite news |last=Kravets |first=David |date=26 April 2017 |title=Palantir settles US charges that it discriminated against Asian engineers |publisher=Ars Technica |url=https://arstechnica.com/tech-policy/2017/04/palantir-settles-us-charges-it-discriminated-against-asian-engineers/ |url-status=live |access-date=26 April 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201028133450/https://arstechnica.com/tech-policy/2017/04/palantir-settles-us-charges-it-discriminated-against-asian-engineers/ |archive-date=28 October 2020}}</ref>

===British Parliament inquiry (2018)===
During questioning in front of the [[Digital, Culture, Media and Sport Committee|Digital, Culture, Media and Sport Select Committee]], [[Christopher Wylie]], the former research director of [[Cambridge Analytica]], said that several meetings had taken place between Palantir and Cambridge Analytica, and that Alexander Nix, the chief executive of [[SCL Group|SCL]], had facilitated their use of [[Aleksandr Kogan (scientist)|Aleksandr Kogan]]'s data which had been obtained from his app "thisisyourdigitallife" by mining personal surveys. Kogan later established Global Science Research to share the data with Cambridge Analytica and others. Wylie confirmed that both employees from Cambridge Analytica and Palantir used Kogan's Global Science Research and harvested Facebook data together in the same offices.<ref name="Guardian180327Pegg">{{Cite news |last1=Pegg |first1=David |last2=Cadwalladr |first2=Carole |author-link2=Carole Cadwalladr |date=March 27, 2018 |title=US data firm admits employee approached Cambridge Analytica: Palantir confirm employee 'engaged in a personal capacity' with the company |work=The Guardian |url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2018/mar/28/palantir-employee-cambridge-analytica |url-status=live |access-date=April 23, 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201028133402/https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2018/mar/28/palantir-employee-cambridge-analytica |archive-date=October 28, 2020}}</ref><ref name="NYT180327">{{Cite news |last1=Confessore |first1=Nicholas |author-link=Nicholas Confessore |last2=Rosenberg |first2=Matthew |author-link2=Matthew Rosenberg |date=March 27, 2018 |title=Spy Contractor's Idea Helped Cambridge Analytica Harvest Facebook Data |work=New York Times |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/03/27/us/cambridge-analytica-palantir.html |url-status=live |access-date=April 24, 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201028133423/https://www.nytimes.com/2018/03/27/us/cambridge-analytica-palantir.html |archive-date=October 28, 2020}}</ref>

===ICE partnership (since 2014)===
Palantir has come under criticism due to its partnership developing software for [[U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement]]. Palantir has responded that its software is not used to facilitate deportations. In a statement provided to the New York Times,<ref>{{Cite web |date=11 December 2018 |title=DealBook Briefing: Investors May Be Overlooking Their Own Discrimination |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/12/11/business/dealbook/investor-bias-discrimination.html |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190804201053/https://www.nytimes.com/2018/12/11/business/dealbook/investor-bias-discrimination.html |archive-date=4 August 2019 |access-date=4 August 2019 |website=The New York Times}}</ref> the firm implied that because its contract was with HSI, a division of ICE focused on investigating criminal activities, it played no role in deportations. However, documents obtained by ''[[The Intercept]]''<ref name="DeportationMachine">{{Cite web |last=Woodman |first=Spencer |date=2 March 2017 |title=Palantir Provides the Engine for Donald Trump's Deportation Machine |url=https://theintercept.com/2017/03/02/palantir-provides-the-engine-for-donald-trumps-deportation-machine/ |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201028133357/https://theintercept.com/2017/03/02/palantir-provides-the-engine-for-donald-trumps-deportation-machine/ |archive-date=28 October 2020 |access-date=6 November 2018 |website=The Intercept |publisher=The Intercept}}</ref> show that this is not the case. According to these documents, Palantir's ICM software is considered 'mission critical' to ICE. Other groups critical of Palantir include the [[Brennan Center for Justice]],<ref>{{Cite web |title=Palantir Contract Dispute Exposes NYPD's Lack of Transparency |url=https://www.brennancenter.org/blog/palantir-contract-dispute-exposes-nypd%E2%80%99s-lack-transparency |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201028133409/https://www.brennancenter.org/our-work/analysis-opinion/palantir-contract-dispute-exposes-nypds-lack-transparency |archive-date=2020-10-28 |access-date=2019-08-04 |website=Brennan Center for Justice |publisher=Brennan Center for Justice}}</ref> National Immigration Project,<ref>{{Cite web |title=National Immigration Project of the National Lawyers Guild |url=https://www.nationalimmigrationproject.org/index.html |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201028133434/https://www.nationalimmigrationproject.org/index.html |archive-date=2020-10-28 |access-date=2019-08-04 |website=www.nationalimmigrationproject.org}}</ref> the Immigrant Defense Project,<ref>{{Cite web |title=Immigrant Defense Project - Fighting for Justice & Human Rights for ALL |url=https://www.immigrantdefenseproject.org/ |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201028133408/https://www.immigrantdefenseproject.org/ |archive-date=2020-10-28 |access-date=2019-08-04}}</ref> the [[Tech Workers Coalition]] and Mijente.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Mijente |url=https://mijente.net/notechforice/ |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190804200729/https://mijente.net/notechforice/ |archive-date=2019-08-04 |access-date=2019-08-04 |website=Mijente}}</ref> In one internal ICE report<ref>{{Cite web |date=2 May 2019 |title=Palantir Played Key Role in Arresting Families for Deportation, Document Shows |url=https://mijente.net/2019/05/02/palantir-arresting-families/ |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201028133553/https://mijente.net/2019/05/palantir-arresting-families/ |archive-date=28 October 2020 |access-date=4 August 2019 |website=Mijente}}</ref> Mijente acquired, it was revealed that Palantir's software was critical in an operation to arrest the parents of undocumented migrant children.

On September 28, 2020, [[Amnesty International]] released a report criticizing Palantir failure to conduct human rights due diligence around its contracts with [[U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement|ICE]]. Concerns around Palantir's rights record were being scrutinized for contributing to [[human rights violations]] of [[asylum-seekers]] and [[Economic migrant|migrants]].<ref>{{Cite web |title=Failing To Do Right:The Urgent Need for Palantir to Respect Human Rights |url=https://www.amnestyusa.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/Amnest-International-Palantir-Briefing-Report-092520_Final.pdf |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201028133415/https://www.amnestyusa.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/Amnest-International-Palantir-Briefing-Report-092520_Final.pdf |archive-date=28 October 2020 |access-date=28 September 2020 |website=Amnesty International}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |title=Amnesty International slams Palantir's human rights record |url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/palantir-human-rights-record-amnesty-international/ |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201028133416/https://www.cbsnews.com/news/palantir-human-rights-record-amnesty-international/ |archive-date=28 October 2020 |access-date=29 September 2020 |website=CBS News}}</ref>

==="HHS Protect Now" and privacy concerns (since 2020)===

{{Unbalanced section|date=December 2020}}

The ongoing [[COVID-19 pandemic]] has prompted tech companies to respond to growing demand for citizen information from governments in order to conduct contact tracing and to analyze patient data.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Muhlberg |first1=Byron |title=Privacy Advocates Calls for Transparency Over Use of Patient Data |url=https://www.cpomagazine.com/data-privacy/privacy-advocates-calls-for-transparency-over-use-of-patient-data/ |website=CPO Magazine |date=13 May 2020 |access-date=30 November 2020}}</ref> Consequently, data collection companies, such as Palantir, have been contracted to partake in pandemic data collection practices. Palantir's participation in "HHS Protect Now", a program launched by the [[United States Department of Health and Human Services]] to track the spread of the coronavirus, has attracted criticism from American lawmakers.<ref name="Albergotti">{{cite news |last1=Albergotti |first1=Reed |title=Lawmakers call for more transparency in health agency's pandemic data collection practices |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/technology/2020/07/01/warren-hhs-data-collection/ |newspaper=Washington Post |date=1 July 2020 |access-date=30 November 2020}}</ref>

Palantir's participation in COVID-19 response projects re-ignited debates over its controversial involvement in tracking undocumented immigrants, especially its alleged effects on digital inequality and potential restrictions on online freedoms. Critics allege that confidential data acquired by HHS could be exploited by other federal agencies in unregulated and potentially harmful ways.<ref name=Albergotti /> Alternative proposals request greater transparency in the process to determine whether any of the data aggregated would be shared with the US Immigration and Customs Enforcement to single out undocumented immigrants.<ref name=Albergotti />

===Project Maven (since 2018)===

After Google had issues with employees walking out concerning the new contract in partnership with the Pentagon, Project Maven, a secret artificial intelligence program aimed at the unmanned operation of aerial vehicles, was taken up by Palantir. Critics warn that the technology could lead to autonomous weapons that decide who to strike without human input.<ref name=":0" />
